intro: Hyalolepis occidentalis, commonly known as the western hyalolepis, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and produces small, greenish-white flowers. Its botanical features include a taproot system and a distinct, aromatic scent. Hyalolepis occidentalis is often found in open woodlands and is adapted to thrive in arid conditions.
